It is alleged that such proceedings as were carried on four years ago were very distasteful to many of the citizens of the county and for that reason the rank and file of voters are slow to express their choice for fear of the recurrence of hostile feeling. While no doubt man j have de cided views a to whom they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr, Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight hangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in jected in which Mr. Gannaway ias declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. Terrell other than he is for the administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and su far, that is about the main is sue involved between the two candidates for that office. document.text: The office of county treasurer R. L. Burke is being moved today to the ne woffice building at the court house. For a number of years the oaunty treasurers office has been located in the Bank of Appomattox. Mr. Burke stated today that here- efter all those wishing to pay taxes secure dog tags, or transact business with the treasurer, will please call at the new office. The quarters are located on the ground floor of the lew office building across the hall from the offices of th county agent.

With no contests, and only one candidate for county offices, -only 613 voters wont to the polls! There were over 1,800 eltg ble Viters. The total vote by precincts was as follows Court Home, 194 Cheatwood, 8 Chap, 22 Rocks, 25 Pamplin, 04 Walkers Church, 35 Clover Hill, 81 Agee, 47 Oakville, 50 Stonewall, 87. The total vote for the unopposed candidates was For state senator, Charles T. Mos es, 686. For home of delegates, John B. Boatwright 569.. For commonweaths attorney, W. M. Abbitt, 580. document.text: Miss Ruth Moore, long a popular saleslady in the store of H C. Babcock, has given up her position, and will leave Friday for her home near Beck aam. Miss Florence E Caldwel, who teaches m Marion, Va., is spending tbe holidays with her parents here. She had a seri ous operation on her -throat in the Lynchburg Hospital Satur day and her friencs will be glad to know that she is improving inoe being so ill. It is alleged that such proceedings as were carried ou four y ean ago were very distasteful to many of the citizens of the county and for that reason the rank and file of voters are alowto express their choice for fear of the recurrence of hostile feeling. While no doubt man i have de cided views a to Whinm they will vote for, but little or no pub lic demonstrations have taken place throughout the county and while a few public gatherings have been held, the attendance at these meetings have been small and little interest in such meetings have been manifested. For the house of delegates, Col. A. J. Terrell is opposed by D- N. Gannaway, both of Buck ingham. Colonel Terrell being a candidate for what is called the organizations forces and Mr. Gannaway representing t h e antis. In this, like-other county contests, there has been no issue and the fight Thangs chiefly on personalities. In some quarters, the question of the short ballot issue has been in- jected in which Mr. Gannaway las declared himself as opposed to the short ballot, while no such statement has come from Mr. errell other than he is for thé administration policies. As the short ballot, is an administra tion policy, however, it is regard ed that Mr. Terrell is for it, and in fa r, th at is ft hour, r.hw m ain sue involved between the two candidates for that office, With but four more days be fore election more activity is leen on every hand and the poli- ical pot is warming up to a con- dderable degree in some of the ocal fights. document.text: CONCERN Whereas, on April 10th, 1913, a resolution was dopted by he Dem ocratic County Committee of Appo mattox County, providing for a Pri mary Election to nominate Candi da.es for County and District Offi cers of Apjgomattox County,_ an also providing that all can.idar.cs for nomination for County and Dis trict Offices, as well as members of the Legislature of Virginia, should give no.ice of their candidacy, to the Chairman of said County Com mittee, as provided by law, on or before sixty days prior to the date of said primary, and Whcre s, the following persons for the offices set opposite their names, are the only candidates in said county who have filed their notices, according to law, and i n compliance with said resolution, to- wit For Commonwealth Attorney, W. M. Abbitt For County Treasurer, R. L. Burke . For County Clerk, C. W. Smith For Sheriff, H. W. McKinney For Commissioner of the Reve nue, J. H. OBrien For Clover Hill District Officers For Supervisor, F. A. OBrien For Southside District Officers For Supervisor, George Abbitt, Jr. For Justice of the Peace, T W. Moses Now, therefore, I, W. M. Abbitt, Chairman of the Democratic Execu tive Commit.ee of Appomattox Co unty, by virtue of the provision of the Democratic Party Plan, hereby declare aforementioned parties to be the Democratic Nominees for the offices set opposite their respective names, except for State Senate and Member of the House of Delegates, who have been by proper authori ties declared the nominees, to be voted for in the General Election to be held on Tuesday Nov. 2nd, 1943 and as such nominees entit led to the support and votes of all Democrats, the same as if they had been chosen in a primary election, andWhereas, more than one candi date for the office of Supervisor in Stongwall District have filed their notices of candidacy with me, a s provided by said resolution afore said, their names and the offices for which they are candidates res pectively, will be certified by me as provided by Sec. 230 of the pri mary law to the Electoral Board of Appomattox Oouny, to be by it printed on the primary ballot. Given under my hand this 7th day of June, 1943. W. M. Abbitt, Chairman Democratic County Executive Com- mi tee of Appomattox County. 6-10-ltc

document.text: Thé office of the county treasurer this week calls espe cial attention of taxpayers of Appomattox county to the fact that another five per cent tax penalty goes on during June and taxes not paid will be list ed as delinquent. An urgent request has been made t h a t county taxes be paid by June 8 . For that purpose deputies will be in the office of R. L. Burke, county treasurer, on very Saturday and tax-payers are urged to come there to make their settlements.

document.text: Supervisors a n d county of ficials of Appomattox county met at the court house Tues-  day night of this week and agreed to a slashing of the county tax rate and salaries.j The tax-rate will be cut t 1.50 and salaries will be - duced 10 per cent, it fit. agreed. The present i levies run from 1.80 to 1.95. The reduction is expected to cause a bolstering of confidence locally and will be warmly wel comed by tax payers. No con certed demand for a reduction had been made by citizens, but the supervisors and county of f a l s felt that the cut was in .ine with steps already taken by several other counties. The supervisors also felt it best to act in advance of widespread dissatisfaction that might be forthcoming if theratewere not . educed and wisely averted any m a s s meetings of tax payers such as a number of other coun ies have experienced. Th i s act is expected to renew confi dence in the administration of county affairs, and cooperation -vill now be sought in an effort -o avoid drastic cut in upkeep jf roads and the conduct of the jchools. The- statement signed by county supervisors, follows To T h e Taxpayers of Appo mattox Count Realizing the financial con dition of the farmers and citi zens of our county, brought about by the drought of last year, a n d the unprecedented depression whichwe are pass ing, and small demand and low prices for all farm products, and while all of us now receive the lowest salary and compen sation allowed by state laws, but desiring to help relieve the tax burden of o u r people to some extent, hereby express cur willingness and voluntarily agree to accept a ten per cent cut in salary or compensation for the year beginning January 1st, 1932, and pledge ourselves to do everything possible to practice economy in the admin istration of the county affairs, so that the county, school and road levy m a y be reduced to the lowest possible figure. The above ten per cent does not ap ply to the County Treasurer or the Commissioner of the Rev enue, as the reduction in levy automatically reduces their compensation more than ten per cent. C. W. Smith, Clerk R. L. Burke, County Treasurer Jo el W. Flood, Commonwealth Attorney H. W. McKinney, Sheriff J. H. OBrien, Comr. of Revenue J. A. Burke, Supt, of Schools F. A. OBrien, Supervisor Don Moses, Super visor T. E. Owen, Supervisor E. LeRoy Smith, Chairman School Board ,T. J. Ligon, Member School Board j  o! Davidson, Member School Board. ,, 111 viw of the, foregoing, we iu undersififned members of th e Board of Supervisors, whose duty it is to make up the bud get and fix the levy bf the coun ty, desire to state that we wish to do everything we can to low- er the tax rate to t h e lowest possible figure, consistent with sound financing and safeguard ing the institutions of our coun ty. We are sure we can make a substantial reduction in the levy for th e next fiscal year, and agree to make the total levy 1.50 on the 100.00 for all purposes, thus reducing the taxes of the people approxi mately 12,450.00. We real ize this means a substantial cut in county affairs, road building, and length of school term. This includes a reduction in the sal aries and wages of everyone employed by the county, but we feel that an emergency exists , Continued on Page 4

document.text: i We have become trained about the tithe as a means of contributing  to the church, but ,what would you think of a tax tithe, one-tenth, for the Government? R L. Burke, county treasurer, has loaned us a tax ticket of the grandfather of J . C. Davidson, cash- ,er of the Bank of Appomattox, for taxes paid to the Confederacy on January 24, 1865 ----- that would be 75 years ago tomorrpWl The ticket reads Tax in kind. Estimate and as sessment of Agricultural products which are taxed in kind, agreed upon by the assessor ahd the tax payer, and the value of the portion there- o flh which the Government is en titled, in accordance with the pro visions of the Acts of Congress to lay taxes for the common defense and carry on the government of the Confederate States, and an act to amend said act, approved February 17th, 1864. Said estimate and as sessment to be returned to the Dis trict Quartermaster on or before the 1st day of January of each year. . . Uhe tax ticket, which is in good stace of preservation, then has space to itemize the agricultural products qf the tax payer, under the folio,wing headings Corn, short corn, buck wheat, rice, Irish potatoes, cured fodder, sugar, molasses of cane, mo lasses of sorghum, cotton, peas, jeans, ground peas.  Opposite each item is space for listing the gross  quantity, deductions, quality, tithe of one tenth and value of tenth. The tax payer, in this case, Mr. Davidson, had to pay for a tithe of  20 bushels of corn he grew 260 bushels of corn but was allowed a deduction of 60 bushels fed to pork or 6.00 in cash tithe of 9 bushels of Irish potatoes, or 1.35 in cash ahd tithe of 150 pounds of cured fodder, or 30 cents in cash total tax of 7.65. He had to make af fidavit for the truthfulness of the statement, and that he had 13 hogs to eat the 50 bushels oi rorn ey ducted.  Are your taxes heavy? Perhaps so, but at least you dont have to tithe! 1 We thank Mr. Burke and Mr. Davidson for loaning us this inter esting sidelight on conditions in Ap pomattox 75 years ago.

The remainder of the time it my office in The Bank of Ap bomattox- I Since taxes are a first lien m your personal property as well as real estate, it is most important that you get your axes paid before Dec. 4, 1930 when a 5 penalty is added o all unpaid bills. It is always good business co pay your taxes before the penalty s added, but is es pecially so this year in view bf the business depression as it costs you from 10 to 20 interests o allow tickets to go an penalty. In order to meet the running expenses of the schools, roads, and other current expenses of your County promptly, and to save yourselves the addition al expenes caused by delay, I hope that there will be few tax payers Who w i l l allow their taxes to go on penalty.
